Title.evidence: Nonspecific low back pain is prevalent, and electroacupuncture is one potential treatment option.

Intervention.evidence: Six studies used electroacpuncture with standard therapy compared to standard therapy alone. Four studies compared electroacupuncture with manual needling therapies.

Objective.evidence: This systematic review and meta-analysis aimed to assess the efficacy of electroacupuncture for nonspecific low back pain in comparison to standard therapy and manual needling therapy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Outcomes measured included the Visual Analog Scale and Numerical Rating Scale.

Result_Outcome.evidence: electroacupuncture with standard therapy resulted in a statistically significant large effect in reduction in pain (standardized mean difference (SMD) -0.83, 95% CI -1.22; -0.43, P < 0.0001)
